block.p: Today's KEY GAMES

NO. 1 NEBRASKA 1-0 NO. 23 at NOTRE DAME 1-0 Notre Dame, improved this year, held favored Texas A&M to 255 yards last Saturday. The Irish face a stiffer test against Nebraska, which rolled up 596 yards (505 rushing) against San Jose State. Still, Coach Bob Davie of Notre Dame, said: ''With a young quarterback and a not-real-confident defense, I think we showed a solid foundation on which to build.'' TV: NBC, 2:30 p.m.
Today's KEY GAMES

NO. 1 NEBRASKA 1-0 NO. 23 at NOTRE DAME 1-0 Notre Dame, improved this year, held favored Texas A&M to 255 yards last Saturday. The Irish face a stiffer test against Nebraska, which rolled up 596 yards (505 rushing) against San Jose State. Still, Coach Bob Davie of Notre Dame, said: ''With a young quarterback and a not-real-confident defense, I think we showed a solid foundation on which to build.'' TV: NBC, 2:30 p.m.

NO. 4 MIAMI 1-0 NO. 15 at WASHINGTON 1-0 Two offensive powerhouses. Washington's quarterback, Marques Tuiasosopo, passed for 223 yards and ran for 80 against Idaho and his teammates collected four fumble recoveries, an interception and a blocked punt. TV: ABC, 3:30 p.m.

NO. 2 FLORIDA STATE 1-0 vs. GEORGIA TECH 1-0 Florida State held Brigham Young to minus-2 yards rushing. Georgia Tech is better than it showed against Central Florida, when it needed two touchdown passes in the last four minutes to win.TV: ABC, 8 p.m.
OTHER GAMES

EAST Louisiana Tech (1-1) at Penn State (0-2) Penn State rushed for only 6 yards against Southern California and 30 against Toledo. Tailback Larry Johnson says the fault is in using the same system for years.
Boston College (0-1) at Army (0-1) Both have struggling offenses. Boston College has better talent.
Buffalo (0-1) at Rutgers (1-0) Rutgers, with a creative passing game, may become a decent team.
SOUTH No. 9 Georgia (1-0) at South Carolina (1-0) South Carolina ended its 21-game losing streak just in time. TV: ESPN2, 3:30 p.m.
Vanderbilt (0-1) at No. 13 Alabama (0-1) Alabama couldn't handle U.C.L.A.'s blitz. This should be more comfortable.
MIDWEST Oregon (1-0) at No. 5 Wisconsin (1-0) Wisconsin, with players serving N.C.A.A. suspensions, must step up against an aggressive defense.
Rice (1-0) at No. 3 Michigan (1-0) John Navarre, who had never taken a college snap, threw four touchdown passes for Michigan against Bowling Green. TV: CH9, Noon
Marshall (1-0) at No. 24 Michigan State (0-0) This figures to be the end of Marshall's 18-game winning streak, the best in Division I-AA. TV: ESPN, Noon
Syracuse (1-0) at Cincinnatti (1-0) Syracuse's running game should thrive, even after fullback Kyle Johnson's surgery for a broken ankle. TV: MSG, 3:30 p.m.
FAR WEST Colorado (0-1) at No. 11 So. California (1-0) The Colorado offense, which gained 532 yards in a loss to Colorado State, faces a Trojan defense that held Penn State to 10 first downs.
No.18 Ohio State (1-0) at Arizona (1-0) Ohio State's defense (four touchdowns against Fresno State) appears too strong. TV: FSNY, Noon
Fresno State (0-1) at No. 16 U.C.L.A. (1-0) Ryan McCann is U.C.L.A.'s quarterback because Cory Paus separated his throwing shoulder on the first play against Alabama.
No. 22 Texas Christian (0-0) at Nevada (0-1) More woes for Nevada, which totaled minus-3 yards rushing against Oregon.
No. 21 Illinois (1-0) at San Diego State (0-1) Should be easy for Illinois, which stopped Middle Tennessee three times inside the 10-yard line. TV: ESPN2, 10 p.m.
MISMATCHES Louisiana-Lafayette (0-1) at No. 6 Texas (0-0) Texas, with Chris Simms or Major Applewhite or both at quarterback, is a heavy favorite.

Middle Tennessee (0-1) at No. 8 Florida (1-0) Florida was so mediocre against Ball State that the Gator fans booed their team, leading Coach Steve Spurrier to say, ''We won't be too full of ourselves after this one.''
Kent (0-1) at No. 14 Purdue (1-0) Purdue held Central Michigan to 161 yards and could do it again.
Arkansas State (0-1) at No. 20 Oklahoma (1-0) In routing Texas-El Paso, Oklahoma turned seven turnovers into five touchdowns.
Rankings by Associated Press. All times are Eastern.
